skills.name: Calculate the area of a rectangle where the dimensions are given in the same units
Calculate the perimeter of a rectilinear shape by adding lengths expressed in the same units
Calculate compound area involving just rectangles and squares, where the dimensions are given in the same units
Calculate missing lengths of shapes by geometrical inference, where the lengths given are in the same units

explanations.A: Not quite. It looks like you multiplied the wrong two numbers together. Have a closer look at the diagram, what is the length of the shaded rectangle?
explanations.B: Be careful. Remember, to find the area of a rectangle we calculate width ✕ length.
explanations.C: Be careful. 11cm is not a length of the shaded rectangle. 5cm is the width but you will need to find the height before you can find the area.
explanations.D: Area of the purple rectangle = width × length = 5 × 12 = 60 cm²

explanations.A: Area of the purple rectangle = width × length = 6 × 14 = 84 cm²
explanations.B: Be careful. 8cm is not the length of the shaded rectangle. 6cm is the width but you will need to find the correct length before you can find the area.
explanations.C: Be careful. Remember, to find the area of a rectangle we calculate width ✕ length.
explanations.D: Not quite. It looks like you multiplied the wrong two numbers together. Have a closer look at the diagram, what is the length of the shaded rectangle?

explanations.A: Not quite. It looks like you multiplied the wrong two numbers together. Have a closer look at the diagram, what is the length of the shaded rectangle?
explanations.B: Not quite. I think you have miscalculated the length of the shaded rectangle. What would you have to subtract from the 11cm to find this length?
explanations.C: Not quite. I think you have miscalculated the length of the shaded rectangle. What would you have to subtract from the 11cm to find this length?
explanations.D: Area of the blue rectangle = width × length. We need its length. Looking at the horizontal measurements, length = 11 − 5 = 6 cm. Therefore, area = 4 × 6 = 24 cm²

explanations.A: Not quite. I think you have miscalculated the length of the shaded rectangle. What would you have to subtract from the 13cm to find this length?
explanations.B: Not quite. Before we can calculate the area of the shaded rectangle we need to identify the correct width and length. How can you use subtraction to do this?
explanations.C: Area of the blue rectangle = width × length. We need its width and length. Looking at the vertical measurement, width = 14 − 8 = 6 cm, and for length, the horizontal measurements give 13 − 6 = 7 cm. Therefore, area = 6 × 7 = 42 cm²
explanations.D: Not quite. I think you have miscalculated the width of the shaded rectangle. What would you have to subtract from the 14cm to find this width?

explanations.A: Area of the green rectangle = width × length. Therefore, area = 4 × 11 = 44 cm²
explanations.B: Be careful. I think you have miscalculated one of the lengths of the shaded rectangle. Both lengths of the rectangle can be found on the diagram. Can you spot them?
explanations.C: Not quite. To find the area of a rectangle we calculate length ✕ width.
explanations.D: Not quite. It looks like you multiplied the wrong two numbers together. Have a closer look at the diagram, what is the length of the shaded rectangle?

explanations.A: Be careful. I think you have miscalculated the width of the shaded rectangle. What would you have to subtract from 14cm to find this width?
explanations.B: Area of the green rectangle = width × length. We need its width. Looking at the vertical measurements, width = 14 − 8 = 6 cm. Therefore, area = 6 × 13 = 78 cm²

explanations.D: Not quite. To find the area of a rectangle we calculate length ✕ width.

explanations.A: Be careful. I think you have miscalculated some of the missing lengths. To help, think about what the total of all the vertical lengths on the left hand side of the shape would have to be and then repeat for the horizontal lengths. How can you use these totals to find the missing lengths?
explanations.B: Be careful. I think you have miscalculated some of the missing lengths. To help, think about what the total of all the vertical lengths on the left hand side of the shape would have to be and then repeat for the horizontal lengths. How can you use these totals to find the missing lengths?
explanations.C:
The perimeter is the sum of all the lengths around the outside of the shape. Two of the lengths are missing. The missing horizontal length is 10m (23 - 7 - 6 = 10) and the missing vertical length is 9m (22 -5 - 8 = 9).
So, the perimeter is 5 + 7 + 9 + 10 + 8 + 6 + 22 + 23 = 90 m
explanations.D: Not quite. Make sure you add all the lengths of the shape not just those marked. How can you use subtraction to find the missing lengths?

explanations.A: The perimeter is the sum of all the lengths around the outside of the shape. Two of the lengths are missing. The missing horizontal length is 5m (32 - 12 - 15 = 5) and the missing vertical length is 8m (27 - 10 - 9 = 8). So, the perimeter is 27 + 32 + 9 + 15 + 8 + 5 + 10 + 12 = 118 m
explanations.B: Be careful. I think you have miscalculated some of the missing lengths. To help, think about what the total of all the vertical lengths on the left hand side of the shape would have to be and then repeat for the horizontal lengths. How can you use these totals to find the missing lengths?
explanations.C: Be careful. I think you have miscalculated some of the missing lengths. To help, think about what the total of all the vertical lengths on the left hand side of the shape would have to be and then repeat for the horizontal lengths. How can you use these totals to find the missing lengths?
explanations.D: Not quite. Make sure you add all the lengths of the shape not just those marked. How can you use subtraction to find the missing lengths?

explanations.A: Not quite, I think you've miscalculated the width of the green rectangle. Try again :)
explanations.B: Not quite, you will have to do some calculations to find the height and width of the green rectangle :)
explanations.C: You're close but not quite there yet! The width is 10m, but the height isn't 7. Try again :)
explanations.D: Area of the green rectangle = width × height. We need its height and width. For the width, look at the horizontal measurements: 23 − 7 − 6 = 10 m. For the height, look to the vertical measurements: 22 − 8 = 14 m. Therefore, area = 10 × 14 = 140 m²

explanations.A: Area of the green rectangle = width × height. We need its length and height. For the width, look to other horizontal measurements: 32 − 12 − 15 = 5 m. For the height, look to other vertical measurements: 27 − 10 = 17 m. Therefore, area = 5 × 17 = 85 m²
explanations.B: Not quite, you will need to calculate the width and height of the green rectangle first :)
explanations.C: Not quite, try finding the height of the green rectangle again first :)
explanations.D: Nearly! The height is correct, try calculating the width of the green rectangle again
